text.more:
Navigating the DPIM2 Map
Looking Around
Zooming In and Out:
If you want to see more closely, like looking with a magnifying glass, you use the scroll wheel on the mouseâ€”roll it forward to look closer and backward to see more from afar.
Moving the Picture:
If the protein you want to see is not in the center, press down on the empty space with the mouse button, hold it, and move the mouse.
Finding Specific Proteins
Search function:
Type the beginning of a protein name to find the gene of interest. It would show the protein information and zoom in to the protein's direct interactor subnetwork.
Using Colors:
Each color on the map represents a cluster of proteins that have function in common.
Clicking on Dots and Lines:
When you click on a dot (a protein), a little box will pop up, giving you more information like protein name and who interactors are.
text.intro: DPIM2 - established from affinity purification-mass spectrometry of 5,805 baits covering the largest fraction yet of the Drosophila proteome. It contains 32,668 interactions among 3,644 proteins, organized into 632 clusters representing putative functional modules
text.title: DPIM2 - The next-generation Drosophila Protein Interaction Map
